title: Sprint Story 3: Dependencies Update, Testing & Documentation
body:
## ğŸ“‹ Sprint Story Description

**Parent Issue**: #2 - Upgrade project to latest versions of Spring Boot, Java, and dependencies

**Epic**: Infrastructure Modernization  
**Story Points**: 5  
**Sprint**: 1  
**Assignee**: Developer C (QA/Testing focus)

## ğŸ¯ User Story
As a developer, I want to upgrade all third-party dependencies and update project documentation so that the application has the latest security patches and developers have accurate setup instructions.

## ğŸ”§ Technical Tasks
- [ ] Update JGit dependency from 4.8.0 to 6.x (merge PR #1)
- [ ] Update all other Maven dependencies to latest compatible versions
- [ ] Run dependency vulnerability scans
- [ ] Update Maven plugins to latest versions
- [ ] Update README.md with new version information
- [ ] Update build instructions for new Java/Maven versions
- [ ] Update API documentation if endpoints changed
- [ ] Update troubleshooting guide
- [ ] Create comprehensive test suite for all functionality
- [ ] Document any breaking changes or migration notes

## ğŸ“‹ Acceptance Criteria

### AC1: Dependencies Update
- **Given** the project has outdated third-party dependencies
- **When** I update all dependencies to latest stable versions
- **Then** all dependencies should be compatible with Spring Boot 3.x and Java 21
- **And** no security vulnerabilities should be present

### AC2: JGit Integration
- **Given** there's a pending Dependabot PR for JGit update
- **When** I merge and test the JGit 6.x update
- **Then** Git repository integration should work without issues
- **And** all Git-related functionality should be preserved

### AC3: Documentation Accuracy
- **Given** the project versions have changed significantly
- **When** I update all documentation
- **Then** README.md should reflect current versions and requirements
- **And** all setup instructions should be accurate and tested

### AC4: Vulnerability Assessment
- **Given** security is a priority
- **When** I run dependency vulnerability scans
- **Then** no high or critical vulnerabilities should be present
- **And** all security recommendations should be addressed

### AC5: Testing Coverage
- **Given** major upgrades have been made
- **When** I create comprehensive test scenarios
- **Then** all functionality should be covered by tests
- **And** edge cases and error scenarios should be tested

## ğŸ“ Files to Modify
- `pom.xml` (all dependencies and plugins)
- `README.md` (version information, setup instructions)
- Test files (comprehensive test coverage)
- Configuration files (if needed for new dependency versions)

## ğŸ§ª Testing Strategy
- [ ] Dependency compatibility testing
- [ ] Security vulnerability scanning
- [ ] End-to-end functionality testing
- [ ] Performance regression testing
- [ ] Integration testing with Git repositories
- [ ] Cross-environment testing
- [ ] Load testing for config server endpoints

## ğŸ“Š Effort Estimation
- **Story Points**: 5
- **Hours**: 10-16 hours
- **Complexity**: Medium (dependency management and testing)
- **Risk**: Low-Medium (mostly testing and documentation)

## ğŸ”„ Dependencies
- **Depends on**: Sprint Story 1 & 2 (Java and Spring upgrades)
- **Blocks**: None (final story in the upgrade sequence)

## ğŸ” Security Checklist
- [ ] Run `mvn dependency:tree` to check for conflicts
- [ ] Use `mvn versions:display-dependency-updates` for updates
- [ ] Run OWASP dependency check
- [ ] Review security advisories for all dependencies
- [ ] Test with different JVM security settings

## âœ… Definition of Done
- [ ] All dependencies updated to latest compatible versions
- [ ] JGit 6.x is working correctly (PR #1 resolved)
- [ ] No security vulnerabilities in dependencies
- [ ] All Maven plugins updated
- [ ] README.md accurately reflects new versions
- [ ] Build instructions tested and verified
- [ ] Comprehensive test suite created and passing
- [ ] Documentation review completed
- [ ] Performance testing shows no regressions
- [ ] Code review completed

## ğŸ“‹ Testing Checklist
- [ ] Application builds with `mvnw clean install`
- [ ] All unit tests pass
- [ ] All integration tests pass
- [ ] Git repository operations work correctly
- [ ] Config server endpoints respond within acceptable time
- [ ] Memory usage is within acceptable limits
- [ ] Application starts in under 30 seconds
- [ ] Health checks pass
- [ ] All documented features work as described

## ğŸ“Š Documentation Updates Required
- [ ] Update technology versions in README.md
- [ ] Update prerequisite versions (Java 21, Maven 3.9+)
- [ ] Update build commands and examples
- [ ] Update troubleshooting section
- [ ] Add migration notes if needed
- [ ] Update API endpoint documentation
- [ ] Update configuration examples

## ğŸ”§ Tools and Commands
```bash
# Dependency updates
mvn versions:display-dependency-updates
mvn versions:display-plugin-updates

# Security scanning
mvn org.owasp:dependency-check-maven:check

# Testing
mvn clean test
mvn clean integration-test
```

## ğŸ“‹ Validation Criteria
- [ ] Zero critical or high security vulnerabilities
- [ ] All dependencies have compatible licenses
- [ ] No deprecated dependencies in use
- [ ] All tests pass consistently
- [ ] Documentation is clear and accurate
- [ ] Performance meets or exceeds current benchmarks

title: Remove transparent proxy note from the doc
body:
### Version

4.5.15

### Context

The documentation describes `vertx-http-proxy` as a transparent proxy, but it isn't. Implementing a transparent proxy requires features beyond the scope of this project (see https://www.haproxy.com/documentation/haproxy-configuration-manual/latest/#4.2-option%20transparent)

title: API Documentation with Swagger
body:
## ğŸ“‹ Feature Description
Add comprehensive API documentation using Swagger/OpenAPI with interactive documentation interface and detailed endpoint specifications.

## ğŸ¯ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Add Swagger/OpenAPI dependencies
- [ ] Configure Swagger UI
- [ ] Add API documentation annotations
- [ ] Generate interactive API documentation
- [ ] Add example requests/responses

## ğŸ”— Dependencies
- Depends on: #5 (Basic CRUD Endpoints)
- Depends on: #6 (Search Endpoint Implementation)

## ğŸ“ Implementation Details
**Dependencies to Add:**
- `springdoc-openapi-starter-webmvc-ui` (Spring Boot 3.x compatible)
- Configure OpenAPI version 3.0

**Swagger Configuration:**
- Configure OpenAPI info (title, description, version, contact)
- Set up security schemes if needed
- Configure server information
- Custom Swagger UI path: `/api-docs`

**API Documentation Annotations:**
- `@Tag` - Group related endpoints
- `@Operation` - Document individual endpoints
- `@Parameter` - Document request parameters
- `@RequestBody` - Document request body schemas
- `@ApiResponse` - Document response codes and schemas
- `@Schema` - Document data models

**Documentation Coverage:**
- All Movie CRUD endpoints
- Search endpoints with query parameters
- Review endpoints (if implemented)
- Error response schemas
- Input validation documentation

**Example Requests/Responses:**
- Sample JSON for movie creation/updates
- Example search queries
- Error response examples
- Pagination response examples

**Swagger UI Features:**
- Interactive \"Try it out\" functionality
- Request/response examples
- Model schemas
- Parameter validation
- Download OpenAPI specification

## âœ… Definition of Done
- [ ] Code is written and follows Java/Spring Boot best practices
- [ ] Unit tests are written and passing
- [ ] Integration tests are written and passing (where applicable)
- [ ] Code is documented with JavaDoc where appropriate
- [ ] Feature works as expected when tested manually
- [ ] No breaking changes to existing functionality
- [ ] Code is committed to Git with meaningful commit messages

## ğŸ§ª Testing Strategy
- Verify Swagger UI loads correctly at configured endpoint
- Test \"Try it out\" functionality for all endpoints
- Validate OpenAPI specification generation
- Test that all endpoints are properly documented
- Verify model schemas are accurate and complete
- Test example requests/responses work correctly

## ğŸ“š Additional Notes
- Swagger UI should be accessible at `/swagger-ui/index.html`
- OpenAPI JSON available at `/v3/api-docs`
- Consider organizing endpoints into logical groups/tags
- Ensure sensitive information is not exposed in documentation
- Add clear descriptions for all endpoints and parameters
- Include HTTP status code documentation for all responses

title: [DOCUMENTATION] Documentation and README
body:
## ğŸ“‹ Feature Description
Create comprehensive project documentation including detailed README, API documentation, setup instructions, and troubleshooting guide to ensure easy onboarding and maintenance.

## ğŸ¯ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Create comprehensive README.md with project overview
- [ ] Add setup and installation instructions
- [ ] Document all API endpoints with examples
- [ ] Add Docker run instructions
- [ ] Include testing instructions
- [ ] Add troubleshooting section
- [ ] Create API documentation (markdown or OpenAPI)
- [ ] Add contributing guidelines

## ğŸ”— Dependencies
- Depends on: #9 (Dockerization)

## ğŸ“ Implementation Details
### README Sections:
1. **Project Overview**
   - Description and purpose
   - Features and capabilities
   - Technology stack
   - Architecture overview

2. **Quick Start**
   - Prerequisites
   - Installation steps
   - Running the application
   - Basic usage examples

3. **API Documentation**
   - Endpoint listing with HTTP methods
   - Request/response examples
   - Query parameters
   - Error codes and responses

4. **Development Setup**
   - Local development environment
   - Database setup
   - IDE configuration
   - Running tests

5. **Docker Instructions**
   - Building Docker images
   - Running with docker-compose
   - Environment configuration
   - Production deployment

6. **Testing Guide**
   - Running unit tests
   - Running integration tests
   - Manual testing with Postman
   - Test data and fixtures

7. **Troubleshooting**
   - Common issues and solutions
   - Database connection problems
   - Port conflicts
   - Performance issues

### API Documentation Format:
For each endpoint, include:
- HTTP method and URL
- Description
- Request parameters
- Request body example
- Response body example
- Possible error responses
- Usage examples with curl

### Additional Documentation:
- CHANGELOG.md for version history
- CONTRIBUTING.md for development guidelines
- Code of Conduct
- License information

## âœ… Definition of Done
- [ ] Code is written and follows Java/Spring Boot best practices
- [ ] Unit tests are written and passing
- [ ] Integration tests are written and passing (where applicable)
- [ ] Code is documented with JavaDoc where appropriate
- [ ] Feature works as expected when tested manually
- [ ] No breaking changes to existing functionality
- [ ] Code is committed to Git with meaningful commit messages

## ğŸ§ª Testing Strategy
- Verify all documented commands work as described
- Test setup instructions on clean environment
- Validate API examples work correctly
- Check all links and references
- Ensure documentation is up-to-date with codebase

## ğŸ“š Additional Notes
Good documentation is crucial for project adoption and maintenance. The README should be the first thing new developers read and should provide clear path from zero to running application.

title: [TESTING] API Testing with Sample Data
body:
## ğŸ“‹ Feature Description
Create comprehensive API testing documentation and sample data, then manually test all endpoints using tools like Postman or curl to verify the API works as expected and matches the specifications.

## ğŸ¯ Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Create sample movie data for testing
- [ ] Test all endpoints with Postman/curl
- [ ] Verify JSON request/response formats match specifications
- [ ] Test error responses (404, 400, 500)
- [ ] Document actual API behavior vs requirements
- [ ] Create Postman collection for API testing
- [ ] Add API testing documentation to README
- [ ] Verify all HTTP status codes are correct

## ğŸ”— Dependencies
- Depends on: #7 (Integration Tests)

## ğŸ“ Implementation Details
### Sample Test Data:
Create diverse movie dataset including:
- Popular movies from different genres
- Movies from different decades
- Movies with various rating ranges
- Movies with different directors
- Edge cases (very long titles, special characters, etc.)

### Manual Testing Checklist:
1. **CRUD Operations:**
   - GET /movies - Verify all movies returned
   - GET /movies/{id} - Test valid and invalid IDs
   - POST /movies - Test valid data and validation errors
   - PUT /movies/{id} - Test updates and not found cases
   - DELETE /movies/{id} - Test deletion and not found cases

2. **Search Operations:**
   - Search by genre with various genres
   - Search by release year (past, current, future)
   - Search by minimum rating (various thresholds)
   - Search by director (exact, partial, case variations)
   - Combined search criteria

3. **Error Scenarios:**
   - Invalid JSON format
   - Missing required fields
   - Invalid data types
   - Out of range values
   - Non-existent resource IDs

### API Documentation:
- Request/response examples for each endpoint
- Error response format documentation
- HTTP status code documentation
- Query parameter documentation
- Validation rule documentation

### Postman Collection:
- Pre-configured requests for all endpoints
- Environment variables for base URL
- Test scripts for response validation
- Sample request bodies and query parameters

## âœ… Definition of Done
- [ ] Code is written and follows Java/Spring Boot best practices
- [ ] Unit tests are written and passing
- [ ] Integration tests are written and passing (where applicable)
- [ ] Code is documented with JavaDoc where appropriate
- [ ] Feature works as expected when tested manually
- [ ] No breaking changes to existing functionality
- [ ] Code is committed to Git with meaningful commit messages

## ğŸ§ª Testing Strategy
- Manual testing with real HTTP requests
- Verify response times and performance
- Test with various data sizes
- Validate JSON schema compliance
- Cross-check with integration test results
- User acceptance testing scenarios

## ğŸ“š Additional Notes
This manual testing phase serves as final validation before considering the API complete. It helps identify any gaps between automated tests and real-world usage scenarios.

title: [BUILD] Implement Automated Documentation Generation and Maintenance Pipeline
body:
## Issue Type
- [x] CI/CD pipeline enhancement
- [ ] Build failure
- [ ] Test failure
- [ ] Dependency issue
- [ ] Documentation build issue
- [ ] Performance test issue
- [ ] Security scan failure
- [ ] Code quality check failure

## Build Environment

### CI/CD Platform
- [x] GitHub Actions
- [ ] Local development environment

### Build Tool
- [x] Maven
- [ ] Gradle

### Environment Details
- **OS**: ubuntu-latest
- **Java Version**: 17, 21
- **Build Tool Version**: Maven 4.0.0-rc-4+
- **Documentation Tools**: MkDocs Material, JavaDoc, Mermaid
- **Target**: Automated documentation pipeline with multi-format output

## Enhancement Details

### Objective
Establish comprehensive automated documentation generation and maintenance pipeline that keeps documentation synchronized with code changes, generates multiple output formats, and provides comprehensive coverage across all library components.

**Priority**: Medium  
**Source**: Developer Experience + Documentation Quality Requirements  
**Target**: Version 1.1 (Q2 2025)

### Current State
- Manual documentation maintenance with inconsistent updates
- Limited automation for JavaDoc generation
- No automated validation of documentation accuracy
- Inconsistent documentation formatting and structure

### Desired State
- Fully automated documentation generation from code and configuration
- Multi-format output (HTML, PDF, API reference, tutorials)
- Automated validation of code examples and links
- Synchronized documentation updates with every code change

## Implementation Requirements

### Documentation Pipeline Architecture
```yaml
# .github/workflows/documentation.yml
name: Documentation Pipeline
on:
  push:
    branches: [main, develop]
    paths: ['src/**', 'docs/**', '*.md']
  pull_request:
    paths: ['src/**', 'docs/**', '*.md']

jobs:
  generate-docs:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0  # Full history for changelog generation
      
      - name: Set up JDK
        uses: actions/setup-java@v4
        with:
          java-version: '21'
          distribution: 'temurin'
      
      - name: Set up Python for MkDocs
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.11'
      
      - name: Install documentation dependencies
        run: |
          pip install mkdocs-material mkdocs-mermaid2-plugin
          pip install mkdocs-swagger-ui-tag mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin
      
      - name: Generate JavaDoc
        run: |
          ./mvnw javadoc:aggregate -Dshow=private -Dadditionalparam=-Xdoclint:none
      
      - name: Extract code examples
        run: |
          python scripts/extract-examples.py
      
      - name: Validate code examples
        run: |
          ./mvnw test -Dtest="*ExampleValidationTest"
      
      - name: Generate API documentation
        run: |
          python scripts/generate-api-docs.py
      
      - name: Build documentation site
        run: |
          mkdocs build --strict
      
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./site
      
      - name: Generate PDF documentation
        run: |
          mkdocs build
          python scripts/generate-pdf.py
      
      - name: Upload documentation artifacts
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
        with:
          name: documentation
          path: |
            site/
            target/site/apidocs/
            docs/pdf/
```

### Documentation Generation Framework
```java
// Automated example extraction and validation
@ExtractExample("basic-s3-usage")
public class S3ExampleTest {
    @Test
    void demonstrateBasicS3Usage() {
        // This example will be automatically extracted for documentation
        RangeReader reader = S3RangeReader.builder()
            .uri("s3://bucket/file.dat")
            .withCredentials(defaultCredentials())
            .build();
        
        ByteBuffer data = reader.read(0, 1024);
        assertThat(data.remaining()).isEqualTo(1024);
    }
}

// Example validation framework
public class ExampleValidator {
    public void validateAllExamples() {
        ExampleExtractor extractor = new ExampleExtractor();
        List<CodeExample> examples = extractor.extractFromTests();
        
        for (CodeExample example : examples) {
            CompilationResult result = compileExample(example);
            if (!result.isSuccessful()) {
                throw new DocumentationValidationException(
                    "Example '" + example.getName() + "' failed compilation: " + 
                    result.getErrors());
            }
        }
    }
}
```

### Multi-Format Documentation Generation
```python
# scripts/generate-api-docs.py
import json
import yaml
from pathlib import Path

class APIDocumentationGenerator:
    def __init__(self):
        self.output_dir = Path("docs/generated")
        self.javadoc_dir = Path("target/site/apidocs")
    
    def generate_all_formats(self):
        # Generate markdown API reference
        self.generate_markdown_reference()
        
        # Generate OpenAPI specification for REST endpoints
        self.generate_openapi_spec()
        
        # Generate configuration reference
        self.generate_config_reference()
        
        # Generate provider comparison matrix
        self.generate_provider_matrix()
    
    def generate_markdown_reference(self):
        """Extract JavaDoc and convert to markdown"""
        javadoc_parser = JavaDocParser(self.javadoc_dir)
        api_structure = javadoc_parser.parse_all_classes()
        
        markdown_generator = MarkdownGenerator()
        for package, classes in api_structure.items():
            markdown_content = markdown_generator.generate_package_docs(
                package, classes)
            output_file = self.output_dir / f"{package.replace('.', '-')}.md"
            output_file.write_text(markdown_content)
    
    def generate_config_reference(self):
        """Generate configuration documentation from annotations"""
        config_parser = ConfigurationParser()
        config_properties = config_parser.extract_from_source()
        
        template = self.load_template("configuration-reference.md.j2")
        content = template.render(properties=config_properties)
        
        output_file = self.output_dir / "configuration-reference.md"
        output_file.write_text(content)
```

### Documentation Validation Pipeline
```python
# scripts/validate-documentation.py
class DocumentationValidator:
    def __init__(self):
        self.errors = []
        self.warnings = []
    
    def validate_all(self):
        """Comprehensive documentation validation"""
        self.validate_code_examples()
        self.validate_links()
        self.validate_api_coverage()
        self.validate_configuration_accuracy()
        self.validate_provider_documentation()
        
        if self.errors:
            raise ValidationError(f"Documentation validation failed: {self.errors}")
    
    def validate_code_examples(self):
        """Ensure all code examples compile and run"""
        extractor = CodeExampleExtractor()
        examples = extractor.extract_from_markdown("docs/")
        
        for example in examples:
            if not self.compile_and_test_example(example):
                self.errors.append(f"Code example failed: {example.location}")
    
    def validate_links(self):
        """Check all internal and external links"""
        link_checker = LinkChecker()
        broken_links = link_checker.check_all_links("docs/")
        
        for link in broken_links:
            if link.is_external:
                self.warnings.append(f"External link broken: {link.url}")
            else:
                self.errors.append(f"Internal link broken: {link.url}")
    
    def validate_api_coverage(self):
        """Ensure all public APIs are documented"""
        api_analyzer = APIAnalyzer()
        public_apis = api_analyzer.find_public_apis("src/")
        documented_apis = api_analyzer.find_documented_apis("docs/")
        
        undocumented = public_apis - documented_apis
        if undocumented:
            self.errors.extend([f"Undocumented API: {api}" for api in undocumented])
```

### Build Integration
```xml
<!-- Maven plugin configuration for documentation -->
<plugin>
  <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
  <artifactId>maven-javadoc-plugin</artifactId>
  <version>3.6.3</version>
  <configuration>
    <aggregate>true</aggregate>
    <show>public</show>
    <doctitle>Tileverse Range Reader API ${project.version}</doctitle>
    <windowTitle>Tileverse Range Reader API ${project.version}</windowTitle>
    <links>
      <link>https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/</link>
      <link>https://aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v2/</link>
    </links>
    <groups>
      <group>
        <title>Core API</title>
        <packages>io.tileverse.rangereader.core*</packages>
      </group>
      <group>
        <title>Cloud Providers</title>
        <packages>io.tileverse.rangereader.s3*:io.tileverse.rangereader.azure*:io.tileverse.rangereader.gcp*</packages>
      </group>
    </groups>
  </configuration>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <id>attach-javadocs</id>
      <goals>
        <goal>jar</goal>
      </goals>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>

<!-- Documentation validation plugin -->
<plugin>
  <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
  <artifactId>exec-maven-plugin</artifactId>
  <version>3.1.0</version>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <id>validate-documentation</id>
      <phase>verify</phase>
      <goals>
        <goal>exec</goal>
      </goals>
      <configuration>
        <executable>python</executable>
        <arguments>
          <argument>scripts/validate-documentation.py</argument>
        </arguments>
      </configuration>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>
```

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Core Automation Infrastructure
- [ ] Set up MkDocs Material with automated building
- [ ] Configure JavaDoc generation with proper styling
- [ ] Implement code example extraction from tests
- [ ] Create basic GitHub Actions documentation pipeline

### Phase 2: Content Generation Automation
- [ ] Implement API documentation auto-generation
- [ ] Create configuration reference generator
- [ ] Add provider comparison matrix generation
- [ ] Implement changelog and release note automation

### Phase 3: Validation and Quality Assurance
- [ ] Add comprehensive link checking
- [ ] Implement code example compilation validation
- [ ] Create API coverage analysis
- [ ] Add documentation accuracy verification

### Phase 4: Advanced Features and Optimization
- [ ] Multi-format output generation (PDF, EPUB)
- [ ] Interactive examples and playground
- [ ] Performance documentation with benchmarks
- [ ] Internationalization support for documentation

## Success Criteria

### Technical Success
1. 100% automated documentation generation with zero manual intervention
2. All code examples compile and execute successfully
3. Documentation updates automatically with every code change
4. Multi-format output generation (HTML, PDF, API reference)
5. Comprehensive validation prevents documentation drift

### Quality Success
1. API documentation coverage >95% for all public interfaces
2. Code example accuracy validated through automated testing
3. Link checking prevents broken internal and external references
4. Documentation build time <5 minutes for complete generation
5. Zero documentation-related issues in production releases

## Testing Strategy
- [ ] Documentation pipeline testing with various content scenarios
- [ ] Code example extraction and validation testing
- [ ] Link checking accuracy and performance testing
- [ ] Multi-format output generation validation
- [ ] Documentation deployment and accessibility testing

## Documentation Pipeline Features

### Automated Content Generation
- JavaDoc extraction and formatting
- Configuration property documentation
- Provider capability matrices
- Performance benchmark results
- Code example galleries

### Quality Assurance
- Code example compilation and execution
- Link validation (internal and external)
- API coverage analysis
- Documentation freshness checking
- Spelling and grammar validation

### Multi-Format Output
- Responsive HTML documentation site
- PDF documentation for offline use
- API reference in multiple formats
- Interactive examples and tutorials
- Mobile-optimized documentation

## Impact Assessment

### Severity
- [ ] Blocks releases (critical for documentation quality)
- [x] Blocks feature development (documentation is part of feature completion)
- [ ] Minor infrastructure concern

### Affected Workflows
- [x] Pull request validation (documentation updates)
- [x] Main branch builds (documentation generation)
- [x] Release builds (comprehensive documentation)
- [x] Documentation builds (primary workflow)
- [ ] Performance testing

## Dependencies

### External Dependencies
- MkDocs Material theme and plugins
- Python documentation generation tools
- GitHub Pages hosting for documentation
- PDF generation libraries and tools

### Internal Dependencies
- JavaDoc configuration and styling
- Code example test infrastructure
- API stability and documentation annotations
- Configuration system documentation metadata

## Related Issues

### Documentation Quality
- Connected to usability quality requirements for developer experience
- Related to API evolution strategy for documentation maintenance
- Dependencies on configuration management for property documentation

### Development Process
- Integration with error handling improvements for example accuracy
- Connected to benchmark infrastructure for performance documentation
- Related to ecosystem integration for framework-specific documentation

## Additional Context

### Documentation Strategy
The automated documentation pipeline addresses several critical needs:

1. **Accuracy**: Automated extraction ensures documentation stays synchronized with code
2. **Completeness**: Automated coverage analysis prevents documentation gaps
3. **Quality**: Validation prevents broken examples and links
4. **Efficiency**: Reduces manual documentation maintenance overhead
5. **Consistency**: Standardized generation ensures consistent formatting and structure

### Documentation Architecture
```
Source Code â†’ Example Extraction â†’ Validation â†’ Generation â†’ Deployment
     â†“              â†“                  â†“           â†“          â†“
  JavaDoc â†’ Markdown Conversion â†’ Link Checking â†’ HTML/PDF â†’ GitHub Pages
     â†“              â†“                  â†“           â†“          â†“
Configuration â†’ Property Docs â†’ Accuracy Check â†’ API Ref â†’ Documentation Site
```

### Community Impact
Automated documentation generation significantly improves:
- **Developer Onboarding**: Always up-to-date examples and references
- **API Discovery**: Comprehensive and searchable documentation
- **Integration Speed**: Accurate configuration and usage examples
- **Community Contribution**: Lower barrier to documentation contributions
- **Maintenance Efficiency**: Reduced manual documentation overhead

This infrastructure investment ensures that documentation quality scales with library complexity while maintaining accuracy and accessibility for all users.

title: ## Pull Request Overview
body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR adds OpenAPI (Swagger) annotations across multiple controllers to improve API documentation, replacing Javadoc comments with `@Operation`, `@ApiResponse(s)`, and `@Tag` annotations.

- Added `@Tag` to categorize each controller.
- Annotated endpoints with summaries, descriptions, and response schemas.
- Removed old Javadoc blocks in favor of standardized Swagger annotations.

### Reviewed Changes

Copilot reviewed 5 out of 5 changed files in this pull request and generated 1 comment.

<details>
<summary>Show a summary per file</summary>

| File                                        | Description                                                       |
|---------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------|
| UserController.java                         | Tagged controller and documented user registration, login, profile, auth status, logout, delete, and admin user listing endpoints. |
| FoodController.java                         | Tagged controller and added Swagger docs for add, read, and delete food item endpoints. |
| ContactUsController.java                    | Tagged controller and documented the submit-contact-message endpoint. |
| CartController.java                         | Tagged controller and documented cart retrieval, add, update, remove, and clear operations. |
| BillingController.java                      | Tagged controller and documented create order, payment verification, order retrieval, bill generation, delete, and update status endpoints. |
</details>



<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (5)</summary>

**src/main/java/tech/realworks/yusuf/zaikabox/controller/BillingController.java:158**
* [nitpick] This endpoint lacks @ApiResponses to document possible response codes. Consider adding @ApiResponses with expected responseCode entries for success and error cases.
```
    @Operation(summary = "Update order status", description = "Updates the status of an order by its ID. Requires ADMIN role.")
```
**src/main/java/tech/realworks/yusuf/zaikabox/controller/FoodController.java:59**
* [nitpick] The schema is defined as a single FoodResponse but the method returns List<FoodResponse>. Update the annotation to reflect an array response (e.g., use @ArraySchema or specify type="array" with items).
```
            content = @Content(schema = @Schema(implementation = FoodResponse.class)))
```
**src/main/java/tech/realworks/yusuf/zaikabox/controller/ContactUsController.java:32**
* [nitpick] The method name setContactUsEmailService is misleading for submitting a contact message. Consider renaming it to submitContactMessage or sendContactUsEmail for clarity.
```
    public void setContactUsEmailService(@Parameter(description = "Contact request details") @RequestBody ContactUsRequest request) {
```
**src/main/java/tech/realworks/yusuf/zaikabox/controller/usercontroller/UserController.java:171**
* [nitpick] This endpoint returns List<UserResponse>, but the schema is a single object. Update to an array schema (e.g., using @ArraySchema) so the OpenAPI spec correctly shows an array response.
```
    @ApiResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "List of users retrieved successfully", content = @Content(schema = @Schema(implementation = UserResponse.class)))
```
**src/main/java/tech/realworks/yusuf/zaikabox/controller/usercontroller/UserController.java:110**
* [nitpick] The authentication status response is not defined with a content/schema. Consider adding @Content with a Schema (e.g., Boolean or custom DTO) to fully document the response structure.
```
    @ApiResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "Authentication status returned")
```
</details>

# Documentation According to Arc42

## 1. Introduction and Goals

* [x] Describe context and motivation
* [ ] Define quality goals
* [x] Define stakeholders and their expectations

## 2. Constraints

* [x] Gather technical constraints
* [x] Define organizational constraints
* [x] Describe conventions, standards, guidelines

## 3. System Scope and Context

* [x] Document system context (external)
* [x] Define boundaries to neighboring systems
* [x] Present high-level interfaces

## 4. Solution Strategy

* [x] Explain main decisions
* [x] Describe architectural patterns/paradigms
* [ ] Consider essential influencing factors

## 5. Building Block View

* [ ] Build block hierarchy
* [ ] Describe modules, components
* [ ] Define interfaces, dependencies

## 6. Runtime View

* [ ] Present important processes and interactions
* [ ] Map scenarios (e.g., use cases)
* [ ] Describe communication mechanisms

## 7. Deployment View

* [ ] Map system to hardware/networks
* [ ] Describe deployment
* [ ] Consider performance and availability aspects

## 8. Cross-cutting Concepts

* [ ] Architectural decisions on, for example:

  * [ ] Security
  * [ ] Persistence
  * [ ] Error handling
  * [ ] Logging
  * [ ] Scalability
  * [ ] Internationalization
* [ ] Document concepts clearly and concisely

## 9. Architectural Decisions

* [ ] Collect relevant decisions
* [ ] Document options and justifications
* [ ] Analyze consequences

## 10. Quality Requirements

* [ ] Create quality tree
* [ ] Describe quality scenarios
* [ ] Define evaluation criteria

## 11. Risks and Technical Debt

* [ ] Identify architectural risks
* [ ] Name technical debt
* [ ] Plan mitigation measures

## 12. Glossary

* [ ] Collect technical terms and abbreviations
* [ ] Clearly explain terms

title: Automatische Versionierung mit Git-Tags und Changelog aus der Git-Historie implementieren
body:
## Ausgangslage

In der Datei VERSION steht die aktuelle Version. Sie wird manuell gepflegt.

In der Datei VERSION.md steht die Versionshistorie. Sie wird manuell gepflegt.

Die Commit-Meldung sind undefiniert.

## LÃ¶sungsidee 

Das Repository erlaubt keinen Push direkt in den `main`-Branch

Jeder Merge eines Pull-Requests fÃ¼hrt mindestens zu einer neuen Minor-Version.

- Semantic Versioning mit Major und Minor.
https://semver.org/

- https://www.conventionalcommits.org/

Ein _breaking change_ fÃ¼hrt zu einer neuen Major-Version.

Jeder Merge eines Pull-requests erweitert das Changelog.

- Immer Squash and Merge

Ziel ist eine saubere Versionshistorie mit sinnvoller Commit-Message.
Mit `git rebase` die existierende Versionshistorie reparieren.

## Default-Branch

`main` oder `master` erkennen

VERSION und aktueller git-Tag muss bei Major und Minor Ã¼bereinstimmen.

`package.json`, `Chart.yml` muss mit VERSION Ã¼bereinstimmen

## Merge- bzw. Pull-Request

Branch-Name mit festgelegten Aufbau prÃ¼fen

- Beginnt mit einer Issue-Nummer
- Mindestens ein Wort folgt
- Weitere Worte kÃ¶nnen folgen
- Issue-Nummer und Worte werden mit `-` getrennt.

VERSION muss vom aktuellen git-Tag mindestens im Minor abweichen.

title: Encryption-at-rest quickstart
body:
We need a quickstart guide for record encryption that demonstrates how easy it is use Kroxylicious and its Record Encryption filter to add encryption-at-rest to a Kafka system.

I am imagining something that:

1. Installs Kroxylicious using the Operator to a Kafka Cluster
2. Sets up a KMS with an encryption key.
3. Configures Record Encryption 
4. Produces and Consumes records demonstrating that the records are indeed encrypted.

I believe we want the quickstart to be something that the average developer can follow easily on their laptop in about 5-10 mins.   To achieve this, we should keep external dependencies and choices to a minimum.  With that in mind, I think the quickstart should target a locally deployed KMS (either Vault or AWS LocalStack).

We should write the quickstart in such a way that its content is verifiable/testable in automated way.

We might want to record the quickstart too and make the video/screencast available, but we need to think about maintenance overhead of re-recordings.  We can consider that later.

title: Move existing filter-author quickstart content to this repo
body:
We've currently go [quickstart](https://kroxylicious.io/quickstarts/) content source controlled as part of https://github.com/kroxylicious/kroxylicious.github.io/.

This is wrong, as the quickstart content is release specific.  It should be versioned and released with project's code.

The job of kroxylicious.github.io should be to merely present the quickstart(s) of each release.

title: [TECHNICAL DEBT] Need to create Test Functions in UserDAO
body:
TERMINOLOGY USED:
Technical debt - Technical debt is a metaphorical concept in software development that refers to the future cost incurred by choosing an easy or quick solution now instead of a better, more time-consuming approach.
Test function - In context of Test-Driven Development, test functions is a short, automated piece of code that defines a specific expected behavior of your program, written before the actual feature, and used to guide development and verify correctness.
Test-Driven Development (TDD) - is a software development methodology where test functions are written before the actual implementation. A test function is a short, automated piece of code that defines a specific expected behavior of your program, written before the actual feature, and used to guide development and verify correctness.

title: Need docs for "otel.experimental.javascript-snippet"
body:
The servlet common instrumentation contains a class called [ExperimentalSnippetHolder](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java-instrumentation/blob/main/instrumentation/servlet/servlet-common/bootstrap/src/main/java/io/opentelemetry/javaagent/bootstrap/servlet/ExperimentalSnippetHolder.java#L15) that references a config item of `otel.experimental.javascript-snippet`. This config and a couple of historical commits (#8734 and #8736) seem to indicate that this can be used to inject some text/html into the response coming out of servlets...but we have no documentation for it (or I cannot find it). I also couldn't find any tests that set this property, so it appears to perhaps be untested? Furthermore, I thought we generally avoided putting hyphens in configuration properties nowadays, because it breaks when using env vars (can't have hyphens).

So I think it would be good for us to write up something that describes what this property is and how it might be used.

title: Document mistake - `filter` to `use`
The documentation should flag the 47 unimplemented TDI functions
body:
**Affiliation**
TBD (submitted on behalf of Discord user, sprell)

**Version(s) Affected**
TBD

**Platform(s)**
TBD

**Installation Method(s)**
TBD

**Describe the bug**
The documentation on the mdsplus.org web site is misleading.   It describes details of 47 TDI functions that have reserved op-codes but were never implemented.   However, the documentation does not clearly indicate that they are unimplemented, thus users attempting to call these functions are mystified when they don't work.   The problem was first spotted when attempting to use `SMOOTH()` and `CONVOLVE()` in an expression for jScope to evaluate / plot.

**To Reproduce**
The fine print in the mdsplus.org web site states the following:

```
(Lower case names of operation are those not ready at this writing.)
```
https://www.mdsplus.org/index.php/Documentation:Reference:TDI_INDEX

Also, the `tditest/testing/test-tdishr.tdi` file has a list of the unimplemented TDI functions.

Furthermore, the `tdishr/TdiUndef.c` file lists all op-codes that cause the `No support for this function, today` error to be displayed (i.e., the `TdiNO_OPC` error).

**Expected behavior**
1) Functions that don't exist, should not be included in the documentation.   
2) Or at least, they should be clearly flagged as unimplemented.   For example, 
```
SMOOTH = this op-code has been reserved, but the function has not been implemented.   
```
3) Furthermore, it would add clarity to have a separate section in the documentation for the 47 "reserved but unimplemented" functions.   They should not be described intermixed with the TDI functions that do exist.
4) The best long-term solution would be to implement these 47 TDI functions.

**Screenshots**
n/a

**Additional context**
An interim workaround might be for users to write TDI *.fun scripts that implement some of the 47 functions.

title: Programing Exam Set Up Video
body:
One student from the Spring 2025 term felt that he was a bit unprepared for the Programming Exam and had wished that there was a video tutorial of what the flow of the Programming Exam would be like. For example this could include a video of someone starting a Programming Exam, following through the Honorlock steps to get it set up, and show how to upload their code and a screenshot to the exam. 

This does raise the question that if we want to do this, should we just have 1 video, or should we try to have a different video for each different OS (Mac and Windows for example). 

In order for a TA to take the test, they just need to enter Student mode to be able to access the test. That is if the professors think it's best for us TAs to handle this. 


This was the conversation between the Student and the TA:

`Student: test went smooth for me! glad i took the practice exam twice to know how the flow would go! wish there was a better tutorial on how the test flow would actually go but i guess you just want us to figure that out. `
`TA: Great work! Though I don't fully understand what you mean by wishing there was a better tutorial on how the test flow would be?`
`Student: Like just having a video of someone going thru the current honorlock process and submitting the code. Just feel like it might be helpful? I donâ€™t know if that makes sense. I think it would have taken a bit of the ambiguity of the test itself. Just a thought`

title: Release process
body:
**Problem**

Users should be able to use a version of the project, with a specified version.

**Solution**

- Research the GitHub release process, and implement/provide instructions on how to implement a GitHub release.
- The repository should be tagged with the version.
- The version should be semver with two e.g. 1.2.3 where the first is the major version, second is minor version, and third is build number, in case build failed for the release of the major/minor version.
- The gradle project version , which is part of `build.gradle` , should be overridden in the release build to the version, to enable gradle versioning features.
- The GitHub actions workflows should be updated to create artifacts matching the release.

     - SMS (allow to enable/disable non-prio)
     - Device (allow to enable/disable non-prio)

Note: 
- Make sure to design and implement the notification types dynamically (add, update, active, inactive might be configured by the admin)
- Disabling the notification type  will override the channel notification, even if they are enabled, but enabling the notification type 

### 2. Posted Balance Regular Report
A customer can set a receiving schedule for the posted balance by
- daily
- weekly
- monthly

Note (implement later)
The report will be sent every the following day at 8:00 pm based on the customer's timezone


### 3. Setting the Time Zone by default will be EST
